titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the The Federal Poets records, 1944-2012 MS2322
titlestmt.author: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

publicationstmt.publisher: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2022-05-18 14:42:25 -0400.

repository.corpname: Special Collections Research Center, The George Washington University

did.abstract: The Federal Poets is the oldest continuously active poetry group on the Washington Metropolitan Area. Membership is open to all. Members provide critical feedback for the poet with the objective of improving each others poems. The journal The Federal Poet is published by the organization seminanually and includes the best poems submitted by members.This collection contains meeting minutes, bylaws, historical materials, correspondence and materials related to events hosted by the Federal Poets. These materials cover the very early years of the organization the early 1940s to the late 2010s. These records are not representative of the work of the organization and only document a small number of years, but do have some of the earliest materials including some written memories of the organization by members. The records cover the years 1944 through 2012.
did.physloc: Materials are stored off-site, and will require additional retrieval time. Please contact the Special Collections Research Center for more information.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The journal The Federal Poet is part of the Special Collections book and serials collection. The call no. is PS595 .W37 F43. It is housed off-site. If you have borrowing privileges you are welcome to go into the online catalog and request the box with the issues you wish to use. The Federal Poet If you do not have borrow privileges for library materials please contact Special Collections to request.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material may be copyrighted or restricted. It is the patron's obligation to determine and satisfy copyright or other case restrictions when publishing or otherwise distributing materials found in the collections.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains meeting minutes, bylaws, historical materials, correspondence and materials related to events hosted by the Federal Poets. These materials cover the very early years of the organization the early 1940s to the late 2010s. These records are not representative of the work of the organization and only document a small number of years, but do have some of the earliest materials including some written memories of the organization by members. The records cover the years 1944 through 2012.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Federal Poets is the oldest continuously active poetry group on the Washington Metropolitan Area. Membership is open to all. The original name of the group was the Commerce Literary Society. This name was changed to the Bookfellows Club after only a few months of meetings and then in late 1946 the name again changed to The Federal Poets.

The members meet at the Tenley Public Library on the third Saturday of every month. At the meetings the group members read and discuss their poetry. Members provide critical feedback for the poet with the objective of improving each others poems. The journal The Federal Poet is published by the organization seminanually and includes the best poems submitted by members.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Gift of Judith McCombs, 2013 October 17 (2013.028). This first donation to this collection is material that originated with Ingeborg Carsten-Miller.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Please cite unpublished materials in the following way:
Please provide the title and date of item, catalog number (if applicable it will be found written on the folder), name of the collection, name of the repository, and location of the repository.

Example: James Oglethorpe to the Trustees, 13 January 1876, RG0001 Series 1, Box 4, Folder 3. Records of the Board of Trustees, Special Collections Research Center, Gelman Library, The George Washington University, Washington, D.C.
